Description: Laconian black-figured pottery stemmed kylix (reconstructed from numerous fragments and added plaster; handles and much of the stem modern); dull cream slip; interior: lip glazed with thin reserved bands at edges; on bowl, black-figure decoration consisting of snaky-haired gorgoneion surrounded by pomegranate frieze; added red on snakes' bodies, gorgoneion's eyes, forehead, lips, and tongue; exterior: lip painted black, around rim, one wide and two narrow black concentric bands; below, rim reserved; handle zone reserved save for horizontal handle palmettes with added red; below, frieze of short rays and frieze of small tongues (some with red dots at their centre), separated by groups of narrow and wide black bands with superimposed red; below, frieze of pomegranates above four black bands at junction with foot; at junction of body and foot, modelled ridge in red; foot painted black
Curator's comments: This sherd has been attributed to the Hephaistos Painter, who has been renamed the Boreads Painter (Lane 1933-1934, 131, no 12). The kylix has also been attributed to the Arkesilas Painter (Shefton 1954, 300, no. 9).
The simple pomegranate pattern around the tondo is particular to the Boreads Painter.
